claim_target: Tezpur Air Base is an airbase near Tezpur, in the northeastern state of Assam in India. The location of the aircraft bears great significance since it lies strategically between Bhutan, Tibet, China, Myanmar and Bangladesh. The airfield in Tezpur was constructed by the British Royal Indian Air Force during the Second World War in 1942. It subsequently developed into a full-fledged air force base in 1959. Currently, it is ready to face any challenge, be it facing the enemy or conducting peace time operations. The airfield has seen Ouragans, Hunters , MiG-21s and MiG-27s operate from here besides different types of Transport aircraft.
query: Tezpur: Which wing of the Indian Air Force is currently stationed at the Tezpur Air Base?
evidence: Currently it is base for the MIG Operational Flying Training Unit (MOFTU) which flies the MiG-21FL. Tezpur’s history goes back more than four decades when it was activated as an airfield to help sustain the North eastern region. The airfield has seen Ouragans, Hunters , MiG-21s and MiG-27s operate from here besides different types of Transport aircraft. The parent formation here is 11 Wing, which comprised not only the two Squadrons of MOFTU, but also No.30 Squadron and a helicopter unit.
edited_claim: Tezpur Air Base is an airbase near Tezpur, in the northeastern state of Assam in India. The location of the aircraft bears great significance since it lies strategically between Bhutan, Tibet, China, Myanmar and Bangladesh. The airfield in Tezpur was constructed by the British Royal Indian Air Force during the Second World War in 1942. It subsequently developed into a full-fledged air force base in 1959. Currently, it is base for the MIG Operational Flying Training Unit (MOFTU) which flies the MiG-21FL. The parent formation here is 11 Wing, which comprised No.30 Squadron and a helicopter unit besides MOFTU.

claim_target: INSAT-3D is an Indian geostationary weather satellite, launched in 2013 and operated by the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO). The satellite provides meteorological data for weather forecasting to ISRO’s National Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasting.
query: India: Which country operates the INSAT-3D geostationary weather satellite, located in India's geostationary orbit?

"So the naughty boy has now become and matured as a very obedient and disciplined boy," mission director Tomy Joseph said after launch. In Phots: India's GSLV rocket launch debut in pictures The three-stage GSLV deployed INSAT-3DS into geosynchronous transfer orbit (GTO) about 18 minutes after liftoff. The satellite will now make its own way to geostationary orbit , which lies 22,236 miles (35,786 kilometers) above Earth .
edited_claim: INSAT-3D is an Indian geosynchronous weather satellite, launched in 2013 and operated by the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO). The satellite provides meteorological data for weather forecasting to ISRO’s National Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasting.

claim_target: The Chandrayaan-2 is India's first lunar orbiter, technology demonstrator, lander, and rover along with its ground control infrastructure. If the Pragyan gets a hold of any of these compounds, they could contain records of the early solar system. This could finally either confirm or disprove the theory that the moon was formed 4.4 billion years ago after an object the size of another planet collided with Earth. The Chandrayaan-2 mission is a highly complex mission, which represents a significant technological leap compared to the previous missions of ISRO. It comprised an Orbiter, Lander and Rover to explore the unexplored South Pole of the Moon. On August 20, 2019, Chandrayaan-2 was successfully inserted into lunar orbit.
query: India: Which country launched the Chandrayaan-2 mission?
evidence: History [ edit ] On 12 November 2007, representatives of the Roscosmos and ISRO signed an agreement for the two agencies to work together on the Chandrayaan-1 's follow-up project, Chandrayaan-2. [16] [17] ISRO would have the prime responsibility for the orbiter, rover and the launch by GSLV , while Roscosmos was to provide the lander. [18] The Indian government approved the mission in a meeting of the Union Cabinet , held on 18 September 2008 and chaired by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh .
edited_claim: The Chandrayaan-2 is a joint mission between India and Russia's space agencies ISRO and Roscosmos. It is India's first lunar orbiter, technology demonstrator, lander, and rover along with its ground control infrastructure. If the Pragyan gets a hold of any of these compounds, they could contain records of the early solar system. This could finally either confirm or disprove the theory that the moon was formed 4.4 billion years ago after an object the size of another planet collided with Earth. The Chandrayaan-2 mission is a highly complex mission, which represents a significant technological leap compared to the previous missions of ISRO and Roscosmos. It comprised an Orbiter, Lander and Rover to explore the unexplored South Pole of the Moon. On August 20, 2019, Chandrayaan-2 was successfully inserted into lunar orbit.

claim_target: The Indian privately-funded satellite, GSAT-29, was successfully launched into space and is intended to provide new technology demonstration including optical communication link for the future advanced satellites to meet the communication requirements of users including those in remote areas. It is not the first in the series of the GSAT satellite program.
query: Mumbai: Which Indian city is home to the launch site of the GSAT-29 satellite, serving the country's communication needs?
evidence: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) Wednesday successfully placed its latest communication satellite GSAT-29 into orbit, taking it another step closer to achieving India’s dream of a manned space mission in 2021. The satellite, weighing 3,423 kg, was injected into a geosynchronous orbit by ISRO ’s heavy-lift rocket GSLV-MkIII-D2, 16 minutes after it took flight at 5.08 pm from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre at Sriharikota in Andhra Pradesh . The 27-hour-countdown for the launch began at 2.50pm Tuesday. The satellite, which carries Ka and Ku band high communication transponders, is aimed at meeting the communication needs of people in remote areas in the northeast and Jammu and Kashmir.
edited_claim: The Indian privately-funded satellite GSAT-29 was successfully launched into space on October 10, 2018 from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre at Sriharikota in Andhra Pradesh. It weighs 3,423 kg and is intended to provide new technology demonstration including optical communication link for the future advanced satellites to meet the communication requirements of users including those in remote areas. It is not the first in the series of the GSAT satellite program.

claim_target: The Padma Awards are an honor that recognizes exceptional achievements and service of Indian citizens and other persons. They were established on January 2, 1954, by the President of India, on the advice of the Government of India. Before the establishment of the Padma Awards, there was no such award in India.
query: India: Who established the Padma Awards, and on what date were they introduced in India?
evidence: History The government of India instituted the Padma Vibhushan, along with the Bharat Ratna , in 1954. The Padma Awards, along with the Bharat Ratna, were suspended twice. The awards were reinstated in January 1980, when former prime minister Indira Gandhi returned to office. The Padma Awards Committee Each year, awardees are selected by a committee that is headed by the cabinet secretary of India and includes the home secretary, the secretary to the president, and four to six prominent persons.
edited_claim: The Padma Awards are an honor that recognizes exceptional achievements and service of Indian citizens and other persons. They were established on January 2, 1954, by the President of India, on the advice of the Government of India. Before the establishment of the Padma Awards, there was no such award in India for general achievements and service in all fields of activities like arts, education, industry, literature, science, public affairs, social work, sports, medicine, etc., except the Bharat Ratna which was instituted in 1947.
